headline: Major credit card stocks slide after Trump comments on credit card rates
summary: Investing.com -- Major U.S. credit card and payments stocks dipped after President Donald Trump called for a one-year cap on credit card interest rates, reigniting concerns over regulatory risk for the sector.

content.title: Major credit card stocks slide after Trump comments on credit card rates
content.summary: Investing.com -- Major U.S. credit card and payments stocks dipped after President Donald Trump called for a one-year cap on credit card interest rates, reigniting concerns over regulatory risk for the sector.

headline: Capital One, Synchrony Stocks Fall After Trump Calls for Cap on Credit-Card Rates
summary: Stocks in a range of financial companies fell after President Trump called for credit-card interest rates to be capped at 10% for a year, in his latest attempt to address voters' affordability concerns.

content.title: Capital One, Synchrony Stocks Fall After Trump Calls for Cap on Credit-Card Rates
content.summary: Stocks in a range of financial companies fell after President Trump called for credit-card interest rates to be capped at 10% for a year, in his latest attempt to address voters' affordability concerns.

headline: Barclays, US Bank Shares Slide as Trump Slams Credit Card Rates
summary: The comments increase the political pressure on a slew of card issuers, including Barclays Plc, JPMorgan Chase & Co., Capital One Financial Corp. and Citigroup Inc. Card interest rates — hovering above 20% in recent years — have become a target of US lawmakers on both sides of the aisle, with bills popping up and meeting stiff resistance from the industry.  In pre-market hours in New York, Capital One plunged 10%, while American Express Co. fell 4.9%.

content.title: Barclays, US Bank Shares Slide as Trump Slams Credit Card Rates
content.summary: The comments increase the political pressure on a slew of card issuers, including Barclays Plc, JPMorgan Chase & Co., Capital One Financial Corp. and Citigroup Inc. Card interest rates — hovering above 20% in recent years — have become a target of US lawmakers on both sides of the aisle, with bills popping up and meeting stiff resistance from the industry.  In pre-market hours in New York, Capital One plunged 10%, while American Express Co. fell 4.9%.

headline: Capital One, Amex Shares Sink on Trump’s Credit-Card Threat
summary: Capital One, the largest US card issuer, tumbled as much as 8.2% in New York, the biggest intraday decline in nine months, after the president surprised the industry with a move he said could go into effect next week.  American Express dropped 4.2% and JPMorgan Chase & Co., No. 2 in the card rankings, dropped 1.6%.

content.title: Capital One, Amex Shares Sink on Trump’s Credit-Card Threat
content.summary: Capital One, the largest US card issuer, tumbled as much as 8.2% in New York, the biggest intraday decline in nine months, after the president surprised the industry with a move he said could go into effect next week.  American Express dropped 4.2% and JPMorgan Chase & Co., No. 2 in the card rankings, dropped 1.6%.

headline: Trump's credit card cap would have 'real negative' impact on borrowers
summary: The earnings season's starting bell has rung, and bank stocks are off to the races this week with JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) and the Bank of New York Mellon (BK) set to release fourth quarter earnings results on Tuesday. Additionally, President Trump's suggestion of a 10% cap on credit card fees has dragged down shares of major credit lenders on Monday. RBC Capital Markets analyst Gerard Cassidy speaks with Julie Hyman about the impact a possible executive order could have on credit card companies. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

content.title: Trump's credit card cap would have 'real negative' impact on borrowers
content.description:
The earnings season's starting bell has rung, and bank stocks are off to the races this week with JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) and the Bank of New York Mellon (BK) set to release fourth quarter earnings results on Tuesday.

Additionally, President Trump's suggestion of a 10% cap on credit card fees has dragged down shares of major credit lenders on Monday.

RBC Capital Markets analyst Gerard Cassidy speaks with Julie Hyman about the impact a possible executive order could have on credit card companies.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

headline: Delta, United, Other Airline Stocks Fall on Trump’s Credit-Card Plan. Why It’s Overdone.
summary: Delta  United and other airline stocks were falling early Monday as investors assessed President Donald Trump’s call for a 10% cap on credit-card interest rates.  Airlines make billions of dollars in revenue each year from co-branded credit cards.  Delta said it received $2 billion from American Express in the third quarter alone, up 12% year-over-year, driven by co-branded card growth.

content.title: Delta, United, Other Airline Stocks Fall on Trump’s Credit-Card Plan. Why It’s Overdone.
content.summary: Delta  United and other airline stocks were falling early Monday as investors assessed President Donald Trump’s call for a 10% cap on credit-card interest rates.  Airlines make billions of dollars in revenue each year from co-branded credit cards.  Delta said it received $2 billion from American Express in the third quarter alone, up 12% year-over-year, driven by co-branded card growth.
